bibl.title: Despatch from Beverly Y. Payne to Thomas F. Bayard, January 17, 1888
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: U. S. Legation Monrovia, Liberia, January 17th 1888.
Sir: I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your communication No 9 Diplomatic Series of December 9th 1887, with seven enclosures.

I take pleasure in reporting that I have in accordance with your instruction delivered in perons Mr Ecclaston and Bishop Penick's letters to Mr Barlay Secretary of State of Liberia, and expressed loyaltymy personal satisfaction that this incident was at an end, which was reciprocated by Sec'y Barclay. The copy enclosures I have on file in this Legation.
Refering to my No 2 of the 23rd sell., I have the honor to state that Mr. Taylor saw fit to have me in charge of this Legation in the capacity of Acting Vice

Vice Consul General, to be appointed Vice Consul General immediately after his arrival to Liberia: since his departure, I have heard (unofficially) of his resignation of the position of Minsiter Resident and Consul General to Liberia:. hence I have pleasure in transmitting to you my Bond, which I trust will meet your approval.

Referring to Mr. Taylor's No 10 of 20th September last, in which he stated, "A Bond awaiteth nothing in this Country (Liberia) so far as the United States is censored," I have for my Bondmen the chieves of the most wealthy mercantile business houses in the County, General R. A. Sherman, and the H. J. Moore, (the later of the firm of Moore G. Moore Gen.) both of whom are venoun to have capital in the United States and of good
I am at present unaware of my real position, and what source to person in the management of this Legation.
Awaiting your instructions I am, Sir, Your Obedient Servant
Hon. T. F. Bayard Secretary of State
